messages.content:
You will be presented with a specific measure from a cognitive psychology paradigm in which we would consider you an expert. 

We would like you to identify the latent cognitive constructs that are being measured by this particular measure. 

Many measures can be quantified in terms of reaction time, error rate, or both. We do
not distinguish between these, and you can think of such measures as a
performance metric in reaction time, error rate, or both.  

There are 13 possible responses.

The first 10 responses are cognitive constructs taken from the “cognitive systems”
domain of the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) Research Domain
Criteria (RDoC), contained in the following python list:

constructs = [
    "Attention",
    "Goal Selection",
    "Updating, Representation, and Maintenance",
    "Response Selection",
    "Inhibition/Suppression",
    "Performance Monitoring",
    "Active Maintenance",
    "Flexible Updating",
    "Limited Capacity",
    "Interference Control"
]

Please respond with a dictionary that includes a key called "constructs", 
which contains a list of all of the relevant constructs from the list above.

The dictionary should also contain a key "measure" that includes the name of the measure, 
and a key "task" that includes the name of the task.

If you believe that a measure does not map onto any of the constructs, you should respond an empty dictionary.

If you believe that a measure maps best onto a construct that is not provided on this list, 
you should respond with a dictionary with the key "Other:", containing a description of the construct that best fits the measure.

If you have additional comments or rationale, please include them in the "comments" key of the dictionary.
 
        This is for the Span task.
        
        The subject is presented sequentially with a list of stimuli (e.g., a list of letters), and then is instructed to recall the list of stimuli. The number of stimuli is titrated up or down to increase or decrease load. The main dependent variable is the maximum number of stimuli that can be remembered, which is called the simple span. On some blocks of trials, the sequence of to-be-remembered stimuli is interleaved with an operation like a lexical decision (judge whether a string of letters is a word or not). In this operation span condition, the main dependent variable is the maximum number of stimuli that can be remembered while interleaving an operation, which is called the operation span.

        The measure of interest is: Simple Span.

content.text:
{
    "measure": "Operation Span - Simple Span",
    "task": "Span task",
    "constructs": [
        "Active Maintenance",
        "Updating, Representation, and Maintenance",
        "Limited Capacity",
        "Interference Control"
    ],
    "comments": "This measure specifically captures the additional cognitive load imposed by the interleaved operation. It reflects the ability to maintain information in working memory while simultaneously processing other information. The difference between Operation Span and Simple Span isolates the executive control processes required to manage interference and switch between memory maintenance and task execution."
}

    "measure": "Operation Span - Simple Span",
    "task": "Span task",
    "constructs": [
        "Active Maintenance",
        "Updating, Representation, and Maintenance",
        "Limited Capacity",
        "Interference Control"
    ],
    "comments": "This measure captures the difference between working memory capacity under interference (operation span) and without interference (simple span). }

    "constructs": [
        "Active Maintenance",
        "Limited Capacity",
        "Updating, Representation, and Maintenance",

}

    1. Attention: It directly measures the ability to orient and focus attention based on spatial cues.
    2. Goal Selection: The task requires subjects to select and prioritize the cued location as a goal for attentional deployment.

}

        This is for the Spatial (Posner) Cueing task.
        
        In this task, subjects see a cue, then a central fixation that is flanked horizontally by two possible target locations. There are three types of trials defined by the location of the cue: valid, invalid, and neutral trials. In valid trials, the cue matches the subsequent location of the target. In invalid trials, the cue is opposite from the subsequent location of the target. In neutral trials, there is no cue for the location of the upcoming target.

        The measure of interest is: Valid - Neutral.

        This is for the Spatial (Posner) Cueing task.
        
        In this task, subjects see a cue, then a central fixation that is flanked horizontally by two possible target locations. There are three types of trials defined by the location of the cue: valid, invalid, and neutral trials. In valid trials, the cue matches the subsequent location of the target. In invalid trials, the cue is opposite from the subsequent location of the target. In neutral trials, there is no cue for the location of the upcoming target.

        The measure of interest is: Post-error slowing.

        This is for the Task Switching task.
        
        A task switching task involves a cue (e.g., word such as “magnitude”, ) followed by a target (e.g., a number between 1-9 excluding 5). Subjects respond to this target based upon the specific cue, which can change between trials. There can be multiple cues for the same task (e.g., "magnitude" and "high/low"), allowing one to distinguish cue switch costs from task switch costs. Cue switch cost is the performance decrement when the cue switches but the task remains the same (e.g., "magnitude" then "high-low") compared to when the cue is exactly the same (e.g., "magnitude"). Task switch cost is the performance decrement when the task changes (e.g., "high-low" and then "odd-even") compared to when the cue switches but the task remains the same (e.g., "magnitude" then "high-low").

        The measure of interest is: Cue Switch Cost.

    "measure": "Cue Switch Cost",
    "task": "Task Switching",
    "constructs": [
        "Attention",
        "Goal Selection",
        "Updating, Representation, and Maintenance",
        "Response Selection",
        "Flexible Updating"
    ],
    "comments": "Cue Switch Cost in a Task Switching paradigm primarily measures the cognitive processes involved in updating task sets and redirecting attention based on new cue information, even when the underlying task remains the same. This measure taps into several cognitive constructs:

    1. Attention: The need to redirect attention to a new cue.
    2. Goal Selection: Interpreting the new cue to select the appropriate task goal.
    3. Updating, Representation, and Maintenance: Updating the task representation based on the new cue while maintaining the overall task rules.
    4. Response Selection: Selecting the appropriate response based on the updated task set.
    5. Flexible Updating: The ability to flexibly update task representations in response to changing cues.

    While Cue Switch Cost doesn't directly measure inhibition or interference control, it does reflect the cognitive flexibility required in task switching paradigms."
}

}

        "Attention",

Conjunction search requires more effortful attentional allocation and filtering of irrelevant information compared to feature search. This measure reflects the additional cognitive resources needed for more complex visual search tasks, involving goal-directed attention, selective inhibition of distractors, and managing limited attentional capacity in the face of increased interference."
}

        This is for the Visual Search task.
        
        The visual search task involves identifying a specific target (e.g., a letter T) amidst a number of distractors (e.g., multiple letters L). Performance is primarily measured by the reaction time and accuracy to identify the target. Targets can be presented amongst many or few distractors. When only one feature differentiates targets from distractors (e.g., the only red stimulus in the display is the target), we call this a feature search. When participants must consider at least two features (e.g., find a red X in an array of blue X’s and red T’s), we call this a conjunction search.

        The measure of interest is: Conjunction - Feature search .

content.text:
{
    "measure": "Conjunction - Feature search",
    "task": "Visual Search",
    "constructs": [
        "Attention",
        "Goal Selection",
        "Response Selection",
        "Limited Capacity",
        "Interference Control"
    ],
    "comments": "The difference between conjunction and feature search performance primarily taps into attentional processes, especially selective attention and attentional capacity. It also involves goal selection (maintaining the search target), response selection (deciding whether the target is present), and interference control (ignoring distractors). The limited capacity construct is relevant as conjunction searches typically require more attentional resources than feature searches."
}

Criteria (RDoC), contained in the following python list:

constructs = [
    "Attention",
    "Goal Selection",
    "Updating, Representation, and Maintenance",
    "Response Selection",
    "Inhibition/Suppression",
    "Performance Monitoring",
    "Active Maintenance",
    "Flexible Updating",
    "Limited Capacity",
    "Interference Control"
]

Please respond with a dictionary that includes a key called "constructs", 
which contains a list of all of the relevant constructs from the list above.

The dictionary should also contain a key "measure" that includes the name of the measure, 
and a key "task" that includes the name of the task.

If you believe that a measure does not map onto any of the constructs, you should respond an empty dictionary.

If you believe that a measure maps best onto a construct that is not provided on this list, 
you should respond with a dictionary with the key "Other:", containing a description of the construct that best fits the measure.

If you have additional comments or rationale, please include them in the "comments" key of the dictionary.
 
        This is for the Visual Search task.
        
        The visual search task involves identifying a specific target (e.g., a letter T) amidst a number of distractors (e.g., multiple letters L). Performance is primarily measured by the reaction time and accuracy to identify the target. Targets can be presented amongst many or few distractors. When only one feature differentiates targets from distractors (e.g., the only red stimulus in the display is the target), we call this a feature search. When participants must consider at least two features (e.g., find a red X in an array of blue X’s and red T’s), we call this a conjunction search.

        The measure of interest is: High - Low distractor load during conjunction search.

You will be presented with a specific measure from a cognitive psychology paradigm in which we would consider you an expert. 

We would like you to identify the latent cognitive constructs that are being measured by this particular measure. 

Many measures can be quantified in terms of reaction time, error rate, or both. We do
not distinguish between these, and you can think of such measures as a
performance metric in reaction time, error rate, or both.

        This is for the AX-CPT / Dot Pattern Expectancy (DPX) task.
        
        The AX-CPT task involves viewing a stream of letter stimuli, and subjects make one response if an A precedes an X, and make a different response to any other pair of sequential letters. Compared to a fully randomized design, A’s and X’s usually have a higher probability of occurrence. An example breakdown of pairs of trials could be: 40% of all pairs are AX, 20% are A’s not followed by X (AY), 20% are non-A’s followed by X (BX), and 20% are non-A followed by non-X pairs (BY). In addition to presenting series of letters, another way to implement the AX-CPT task is with different dot patterns that correspond with the different conditions (A, X, Y, and B). This implementation is called the dot pattern expectancy task (DPX).

        The measure of interest is: BX-BY.

content.text:
{
    "measure": "BX-BY",
    "task": "AX-CPT / Dot Pattern Expectancy (DPX)",
    "constructs": [
        "Updating, Representation, and Maintenance",
        "Inhibition/Suppression",
        "Active Maintenance",
        "Interference Control"
    ],
    "comments": "The BX-BY measure in the AX-CPT/DPX task primarily taps into cognitive control processes. It reflects the ability to maintain and update task-relevant information (the cue) and to use this information to inhibit prepotent responses. The difference between BX and BY trials highlights the interference control needed when a non-A cue is followed by an X probe, which requires suppressing the tendency to respond as if it were an AX trial. This measure also involves active maintenance of the cue information and updating of task representations based on the current trial context."
}

    "measure": "AY-BY",

    "constructs": [
        "Attention",
        "Goal Selection",
        "Updating, Representation, and Maintenance",
        "Response Selection",
        "Inhibition/Suppression"
    ],
    "comments": "The AY-BY measure in the AX-CPT/DPX task primarily taps into cognitive control processes. It specifically assesses the ability to maintain and update task goals, inhibit prepotent responses, and flexibly adjust attention and response selection based on context. The difference between AY and BY trials reflects the additional cognitive control required to override the expectation set by the 'A' cue in AY trials, which is not present in BY trials. This measure involves attention to maintain task rules, goal selection to prepare for the expected X target, updating and maintenance of the cue information, response selection based on the cue-probe combination, and inhibition of the prepotent response tendency created by the frequent AX trials."
}

    "measure": "AY-BY",
    "task": "AX-CPT / Dot Pattern Expectancy (DPX)",
    "constructs": [
        "Updating, Representation, and Maintenance",
        "Inhibition/Suppression",
        "Interference Control"
    ],
    "comments": "The AY-BY measure in the AX-CPT/DPX task primarily taps into cognitive control processes. The AY trials require participants to maintain the context (A cue) and inhibit the prepotent response to X, while BY trials serve as a control condition. This comparison reflects:
    1. Updating, Representation, and Maintenance: Participants need to update and maintain the cue information (A or B) in working memory.
    2. Inhibition/Suppression: In AY trials, participants must inhibit the prepotent response associated with the A cue when Y appears.
    3. Interference Control: The AY condition creates interference due to the high expectancy of X following A, which needs to be controlled."
}

    "task": "AX-CPT / Dot Pattern Expectancy (DPX)",
    "constructs": [
        "Updating, Representation, and Maintenance",
        "Inhibition/Suppression",
        "Interference Control"
    ],
    "comments": "The AY-BY measure in the AX-CPT/DPX task primarily taps into cognitive control processes. The AY trials require updating and maintaining the context (A cue), while the BY trials serve as a control condition. The difference between these conditions reflects:

1. Updating, Representation, and Maintenance: Participants need to update and maintain the task context (A cue) in working memory.

2. Inhibition/Suppression: In AY trials, participants need to inhibit the prepotent response tendency created by the A cue when Y appears instead of the expected X.

3. Interference Control: The AY condition creates interference due to the mismatch between the expectation set by the A cue and the actual Y probe, requiring interference control to overcome this conflict.

The AY-BY measure specifically isolates these processes by contrasting the more demanding AY condition with the less demanding BY condition, where no specific expectation is set or violated."
}

content.text:
{
    "measure": "AY-BY",
    "task": "AX-CPT / Dot Pattern Expectancy (DPX)",
    "constructs": [
        "Attention",
        "Updating, Representation, and Maintenance",
        "Response Selection",
        "Inhibition/Suppression",
        "Performance Monitoring"
    ],
    "comments": "The AY-BY measure in the AX-CPT/DPX task primarily assesses the ability to maintain and update context information, and to inhibit prepotent responses. The contrast between AY and BY trials highlights the cognitive control processes involved in managing expectations and overcoming interference. Attention is required throughout the task, and performance monitoring is crucial for detecting and responding to the different trial types. Response selection is involved in choosing the appropriate response based on the maintained context information."
}

        This is for the Flanker task.
        
        In the flanker task, participants focus on a central letter (either F or H) flanked horizontally by four letters (all Fs or all Hs), two on each side. Subjects make one response if the center letter is F and a different response if the center letter is H. The flanking letters sometimes match (congruent) or mismatch (incongruent) the central letter.

        The measure of interest is: Incongruent-congruent.

}

        This is for the Stroop task.
        
        In the Stroop task, subjects see a series of color words (e.g., "blue") presented in different colors (e.g., green). Subjects ignore the word and respond corresponding to the color (e.g., 1 to blue, 2 to green, 3 to red). Trials can be incongruent (e.g., "green" in blue ink) or congruent (e.g., "blue" in blue ink).

        The measure of interest is: Incongruent-congruent.

    "constructs": [
        "Inhibition/Suppression",
        "Interference Control",
        "Response Selection",
        "Attention"
    ],
    "comments": "The Stroop task's incongruent-congruent measure primarily taps into inhibition/suppression and interference control, as participants must suppress the automatic reading response and control interference from the conflicting word meaning. It also involves response selection, as participants must choose the correct response based on ink color rather than word meaning. Attention is relevant as participants need to focus on the task-relevant feature (color) while ignoring the irrelevant feature (word)."
}

Many measures can be quantified in terms of reaction time, error rate, or both. We do
not distinguish between these, and you can think of such measures as a
performance metric in reaction time, error rate, or both.  

There are 13 possible responses.

The first 10 responses are cognitive constructs taken from the “cognitive systems”
domain of the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) Research Domain
Criteria (RDoC), contained in the following python list:

constructs = [
    "Attention",
    "Goal Selection",
    "Updating, Representation, and Maintenance",
    "Response Selection",
    "Inhibition/Suppression",
    "Performance Monitoring",
    "Active Maintenance",
    "Flexible Updating",
    "Limited Capacity",
    "Interference Control"
]

Please respond with a dictionary that includes a key called "constructs", 
which contains a list of all of the relevant constructs from the list above.

The dictionary should also contain a key "measure" that includes the name of the measure, 
and a key "task" that includes the name of the task.

If you believe that a measure does not map onto any of the constructs, you should respond an empty dictionary.

If you believe that a measure maps best onto a construct that is not provided on this list, 
you should respond with a dictionary with the key "Other:", containing a description of the construct that best fits the measure.

If you have additional comments or rationale, please include them in the "comments" key of the dictionary.
 
        This is for the Stroop task.
        
        In the Stroop task, subjects see a series of color words (e.g., "blue") presented in different colors (e.g., green). Subjects ignore the word and respond corresponding to the color (e.g., 1 to blue, 2 to green, 3 to red). Trials can be incongruent (e.g., "green" in blue ink) or congruent (e.g., "blue" in blue ink).

        The measure of interest is: Congruent (i.e., what constructs are engaged when the word and ink are the same color).

        This is for the Stop-signal task.
        
        In the stop-signal task, subjects make a speeded choice response to an imperative go stimulus (e.g., respond with the right or left arrow key to an arrow pointing right or left, respectively), unless they receive a secondary stimulus (e.g., a star presented around the arrow), the stop signal, which tells the subject to try to withhold their response on that trial. One common measure in the stop-signal task is stop-signal reaction time (SSRT), which quantifies the amount of time it takes subjects to stop their response.

        The measure of interest is: Stop-signal reaction time.

    "constructs": [
        "Performance Monitoring",
        "Inhibition/Suppression",
        "Attention",
        "Response Selection"
    ],
    "comments": "Post-stop-signal slowing primarily reflects performance monitoring as participants adjust their behavior based on the previous trial's stop signal. It also involves inhibition/suppression processes that were engaged in the previous trial, attention to task demands, and subsequent response selection adjustments. This measure captures the cognitive control mechanisms that adapt performance based on recent experiences with inhibitory demands."
}

{
    "measure": "High load (e.g., 2-back) - Low load (1-back)",
    "task": "N-back task",
    "constructs": [
        "Updating, Representation, and Maintenance",
        "Active Maintenance",
        "Limited Capacity",
        "Interference Control"
    ],
    "comments": "This measure specifically targets the difference between high and low working memory load conditions in the N-back task. It primarily taps into updating and maintaining information in working memory, with higher loads requiring more active maintenance and taxing the limited capacity of working memory. Additionally, as the load increases, there's a greater need for interference control to manage irrelevant stimuli from previous trials."
}

        This is for the N-back task.
        
        The N-back task presents a series of stimuli in sequence. The subject makes a target response if the current stimulus matches the stimulus presented N trials ago, and makes a non-target response if the current stimulus does not match the stimulus presented N trials ago. N can be titrated up or down to increase or decrease difficulty, respectively.

        The measure of interest is: High load (e.g., 2-back) - Low load (1-back).

content.text:
{
    "measure": "High load (e.g., 2-back) - Low load (1-back)",
    "task": "N-back task",
    "constructs": [
        "Updating, Representation, and Maintenance",
        "Active Maintenance",
        "Limited Capacity",
        "Interference Control"
    ],
    "comments": "This measure specifically captures the increased cognitive demands of higher N-back loads compared to lower loads. It primarily taps into working memory processes, particularly the ability to continuously update and maintain information. The higher load condition (e.g., 2-back) requires more active maintenance of information and demonstrates the limited capacity of working memory. Additionally, it involves greater interference control as participants must manage more intervening items between the target and its match."
}

The subject makes a target response if the current stimulus matches the stimulus presented N trials ago, and makes a non-target response if the current stimulus does not match the stimulus presented N trials ago. N can be titrated up or down to increase or decrease difficulty, respectively.

        The measure of interest is: 1-back.

You will be presented with a specific measure from a cognitive psychology paradigm in which we would consider you an expert. 

We would like you to identify the latent cognitive constructs that are being measured by this particular measure. 

Many measures can be quantified in terms of reaction time, error rate, or both. We do
not distinguish between these, and you can think of such measures as a
performance metric in reaction time, error rate, or both.  

There are 13 possible responses.

The first 10 responses are cognitive constructs taken from the “cognitive systems”
domain of the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) Research Domain
Criteria (RDoC), contained in the following python list:

constructs = [

    "Updating, Representation, and Maintenance",
    "Response Selection",
    "Inhibition/Suppression",
    "Performance Monitoring",
    "Active Maintenance",
    "Flexible Updating",
    "Limited Capacity",
    "Interference Control"
]

which contains a list of all of the relevant constructs from the list above.

The dictionary should also contain a key "measure" that includes the name of the measure, 
and a key "task" that includes the name of the task.

If you believe that a measure does not map onto any of the constructs, you should respond an empty dictionary.

If you believe that a measure maps best onto a construct that is not provided on this list, 
you should respond with a dictionary with the key "Other:", containing a description of the construct that best fits the measure.

If you have additional comments or rationale, please include them in the "comments" key of the dictionary.
